remembered a molecular gastronomy video
that I made 80 years ago showing how to
make liquid chocolate sphericals
basically you take a small amount of
sodium alginate which is from algae and
you put it into a blender with water if
you add it to warm water well the
blenders running you don't get lumps
it's a lot easier to do it that way then
you pour that into a bowl and you have
to let all those air bubbles settle out
of it a couple of hours later and it's
looking good but as you can see it's
still totally liquid and that's because
our tonight won't set even if we put it
in the fridge it is going to stay liquid
the only thing that makes it set is
calcium like the calcium you find in
milk but if you're working with
something that doesn't
have calcium in it you can add calcium
gluconate or calcium lactate
to it so in this case we can add it to
our egg yolks or any mixture that you
want to make into sphericals you can do
this with mix it in and when that
calcium in this mixture comes in contact
with the sodium alginate it will make it
form a gel now if we leave that in there
for long enough it will gel the whole
way through but if we take it out
quickly you just have gel around the
outside the longer you leave it the
thicker the membrane becomes which of
course is very tricky when you're making
these on a miniature scale you have to
work very quickly and very carefully but
that is how I make the miniature egg
yolks and the white of course is just
plain egg white and add the little mini
yolk on top so it's okay there are no
tiny birds being robbed of their eggs
